title: Stack smashing in X86_64 leads to Segmentation fault .

comments.text: Sounds like you didn't disable aslr, or maybe the return address is wrong. On my system, around 0x7fffffffdea0 will correctly execute the shellcode. I'd recommend printing the address of password inside authorize, and ensure that you're getting a static value on multiple invocations and/or look at /proc/sys/kernel/randomize_va_space and make sure it's 0.

@broadway the address of payload that I obtained was from the stack as it will be [esp] so 0x7fffffffe1d0 which worked in GDB crashed in normal  I printed out address via C and used that  0x7fffffffe2a0 which worked normally but crashes in gdb lol
thats why it was working in gdb and not if i execute normally , now it works normally and not in gdb , Anyidea why its happeneing ?
stackoverflow.com/questions/17775186/â€¦  Seems to be the reason but yet the addresses are different :

answers_data.content:
The issue was that the OS pushes some env on the stack which creates this offset in memory when the program is run on gdb ,which can be resolved by removing the env . 
more about this can be found at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/17775186/buffer-overflow-works-in-gdb-but-not-without-it/17775966#17775966
